Empires & Puzzles Lemniss Review: The Astral Dwarf Miner

Lemniss brings a pickaxe to a sword fight, but instead of damage, she digs up massive heals and ailment immunity. This Astral Dwarf might just be the backbone your team needs to survive the current meta of fiends and vegetables.
Lemniss: The Astral Miner Digging Deep for Health and Immunity

Lemniss is a legendary Dark (Purple) hero from the Astral Dwarfs family, released in September 2025. Visually, she breaks the mold of the grim, brooding necromancers we often see in the Dark element. Instead, we get a cheerful, pink-haired dwarf miner who looks like she is whistling while she works. Do not let the playful demeanor fool you; she is a powerhouse support hero designed to keep your team alive through the toughest battles.

Operating at Average mana speed, she functions primarily as a healer and a "protector" against the myriad of status ailments plaguing the game. She fits perfectly into the modern "sustain" meta, where surviving the initial onslaught is key to victory.

The artwork for Lemniss is refreshing. While many Dark heroes are draped in shadows and skulls, Lemniss is vibrant, sporting pink hair and a casual, confident pose with her pickaxe. The "Astral" theme is woven in with the glowing crystals, but she retains that sturdy, grounded Dwarf aesthetic. It is a nice change of pace to have a Dark hero who looks like they might actually be fun to hang out with at a tavern, rather than one who would just steal your soul.
Lemniss boasts stats that are right at the cutting edge of the power creep curve. With a base power of 1238 (before Limit Breaks), she sits comfortably among the top-tier heroes of late 2025.

Her stat distribution leans heavily towards survivability. With 1316 Defense and a massive 2261 Health, she is built to take a beating. Her Attack stat of 1225 is respectful but clearly secondary, which is exactly what you want in a healer. When compared to other modern supports like the recent Temple Summon heroes (e.g., Devyani at 1233 Power), Lemniss is statistically superior in bulk, ensuring she is often the last one standing.
This special skill is a Swiss Army knife of defensive utility.
This is a substantial heal. While some older slow heroes might heal more, 45% at Average speed (especially with modern troop mana generation) is enough to fully stabilize a critical team.

This is a subtle but incredibly powerful effect. Extending active buffs by 2 turns can turn strong effects into game-breaking ones. Imagine extending a Taunt, a massive Defense Up, or a Mana Generation buff. It resets the clock, forcing the enemy to deal with your defenses for longer than they planned.

For 4 turns, your team simply says "no" to Defense Down, Burn, Poison, Mana Stop, and all other nasties. In a meta defined by debilitating ailments, this preemptive protection is often more valuable than a cleanse, as it prevents the damage or effect from ever landing.
Let's break down Lemniss's contribution quantitatively:
With a base HP of roughly 2260 for herself, a 45% heal restores approximately
to her. For a tankier ally with 3000 HP (common with LB2 and troops), that heal jumps to
. Across a full team of 5, she can easily output over
in healing in a single cast.
Average speed requires 10 tiles to charge. However, her Astral Dwarf family bonus provides a

every time she resists a mana reduction effect. Against mana-control heavy teams (like those using Waterpipe or the construct heroes), she can effectively charge faster than Average speed without matching a single tile.
Extending a 3-turn buff (like a standard Defense Up) to 5 turns represents a
in that buff's uptime uptime. If timed correctly with a hero like Ludwig (who provides taunt and mana for 6 turns), you could theoretically keep powerful effects active almost indefinitely.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Astral Dwarf family is specifically designed to counter the "Mana Control" meta that has dominated high-level play.

The resistance to mana reduction is a hard counter to many top-tier defenses. Heroes that rely on cutting mana or slowing generation become liabilities against Lemniss. If you pair her with another Astral Dwarf, that resistance becomes 100%, and she
mana when hit by those effects. The dispel chance at the end of the turn is just icing on the cake, randomly stripping buffs from the enemy team without you lifting a finger.
This is crucial against the "Vegetable" and "Construct" metas where fiends are rampant. Note that this only clears fiends from
when she casts. While it doesn't cleanse the whole team of fiends, it ensures
is not blocked from healing herself, keeping the healer alive.
She takes no damage and receives no effects from minions. This makes her incredibly tanky against minion-spammers.
This is the most important passive for a healer. You cannot stop her from healing with a healing reduction ailment. She will always heal for the full amount.

at the start of the battle is fantastic. It prevents her from being silenced, mana-blocked, or defense-broken before she can fire her first special. It guarantees she gets that first crucial heal off.

While relatively new, Lemniss represents the evolution of the "tanky healer." In the past, heroes like Kunchen or Rigard were staples. Lemniss takes that archetype and layers on immunity and meta-specific counters.
Her stats are monstrous compared to heroes from even two years ago. Her 2200+ base HP would have been unthinkable in the classic era.

Lemniss is Tier 1 material. Her ability to ignore healing blocks, resist mana cuts, and provide team-wide immunity makes her a top choice for Alliance Wars (especially Rush Attack, though she is Average speed, her kit is amazing there) and high-level Raids. She is a direct answer to the frustration of ailment-heavy defenses.
Lemniss does not currently have a costume. This review focuses on her base form, which is already a complete package.
. This is arguably the best class for a healer because of the
talent. A dead healer heals no one, but a revived Lemniss can fire her special and bring the whole team back from the brink.
Maximizes her survivability. With her already high stats, focusing on Defense and Health makes her a fortress. She needs to live to keep others alive.
Lower tile damage, but she is not there to deal damage.
slightly better tile damage for mono teams.
Sacrifices the bulk she needs to survive snipers. Not recommended.
. As a Fighter, she has a chance to revive with 1 HP. If she revives, you want her to survive the next slash attack so she can heal. Every point of Defense counts.
Grants team-wide immunity to ailments, and has self-immunity via Aether power and passives.
Passive resistance to healing ailments ensures her heal always lands at full potency.
Unique utility that pairs aggressively with other strong buffers.
Family bonus punishes enemies for trying to control her mana.
The chance to revive can win games.
Her passive only removes fiends from herself. If the rest of the team is drowning in fiends, her 45% heal might be absorbed by them.
Some players have noted that the fiend destruction on her passive triggers
the heal calculation or concurrent with it, meaning if she has a fiend, it might absorb the heal before being destroyed. This can slightly reduce her self-sustain efficiency in niche scenarios.
While decent, she isn't Fast or Very Fast, meaning she can be outpaced by aggressive rush teams if the board is bad.
Excellent on both Offense and Defense. Her immunity blocks the annoying effects of many war rules and common defenders.
While she is Average, making her Very Fast in Rush wars turns her into a nightmare. Constant immunity and healing make her team unkillable.
The ailment immunity simplifies difficult boss stages where bosses spam burns or poisons.
Lemniss shines when she can keep a team rolling. She is the oil in the engine.
Ludwig gives Taunt and Mana. Lemniss heals Ludwig and extends his Taunt duration by 2 turns. If you can cycle them, Ludwig's Taunt never drops.
Layering immunity. If one isn't charged, the other might be. This team is virtually impossible to debuff.
While she extends buffs, she doesn't make them undispellable. A fast dispeller (like costumed Sabina or a fast sniper with dispel) can strip the immunity she provides.
Heroes that can block passives or family bonuses (though rare) reduce her effectiveness significantly.

If you pulled Lemniss early, you have struck gold. She will carry you through the entire map. Prioritize leveling her. She will keep your 4-star heroes alive in legendary content. Put her in your defense team immediately.
You likely have many purple healers (Kunchen, Rigard, maybe even Hulda). Lemniss replaces them in almost every scenario except where specific minion utility (Hulda) is needed. Her value lies in the
. If you face heavy DOT or Defense Down teams, she is superior to raw healers. She is worth the Limit Break materials for the stats alone.
The community reaction to Lemniss has been overwhelmingly positive, bordering on "this hero is a nuisance to fight."
One player noted, "She is the power healer nobody knew they needed."
A common sentiment regarding her synergy: "Sounds like a perpetual machine to make Ludwig's taunt last forever."

There was some debate about her fiend passive: "The fiend removal seems to come after the heal... surely this is wrong as it’s working as though there’s no passive at all." This is a valid mechanical critique to watch out for.
Another player summed it up perfectly: "Lemniss is instant meta."

Lemniss is not just another healer; she is a fortress. By combining high-percentage healing with the invaluable utility of buff extension and ailment immunity, she secures a spot in the highest tiers of Empires & Puzzles play. The Astral Dwarf family bonus makes her a prickly target for mana control teams, and her Fighter class ensures she is never truly out of the fight until the very end.
If you have her, level her. If you see her on a defense team, bring a dispeller and pray you can kill her before she starts whistling.
An essential support hero for the modern era.
